definition:
A Riemannian metric on a manifold $M$ is said to be [**geodesically
complete**]{} iff its geodesic flow is a complete flow, i.e. iff for
every point $p\in M$ and every tangent vector $v\in T_pM$ at $p$ the
solution to the geodesic equation
$$\nabla_{\dot{\gamma}}\dot{\gamma}=0$$ with initial condition
$\gamma(0)=p$, $\dot{\gamma}(0)=v$ is defined for all time. The
Hopf-Rinow theorem asserts that a Riemannian metric is complete if and
only if the corresponding metric on $M$ defined by
$$d(p,q)\colon=\inf\{L(c), \; c\colon[0,1]\to M,\; c(0)=p,\; c(1)=q\}$$
is a complete metric (i.e. Cauchy sequences converge). Here $L(c)$
denote the length of the smooth curve $c$, i.e.
$$L(c)\colon=\int_0^1 \|\dot{c}(t)\|_{c(t)} \,dt$$ For a proof of the
Hopf-Rinow theorem see Milnor’s monograph [*Morse Theory*]{} Princeton
Annals of Math Studies [**51**]{} page 62.
